summary: The Court of Appeal in Ghana allowed an appeal against a murder conviction in Regina v. Ayaba, focusing on the defendant's insanity at the time of the offense. The court relied on the principles concerning insane delusions as discussed in the Editorial Note to R. v. Grumah (1957) 2 W.A.L.R. 255, applying Section 52(2) of the Criminal Code and Section 137 of the Criminal Procedure Code. The decision underscores the importance of psychiatric evaluation in determining criminal responsibility.
rationaleHighlights: Defendant suffered from an insane delusion at the time of the offense
Application of Section 52(2) of the Criminal Code on criminal responsibility
Reliance on editorial commentary as persuasive authority
Mental state negated intent for murder
Appellate court reversed conviction based on psychiatric grounds
